  • A proposed RBAC solution and demo.

schedule.title: Feeling a bit deprecated? We are too. Let's work together to embrace the OpenStack Unified CLI!
schedule.description:
Does anyone else recall learning the CLI of the OpenStack projects and scratching their head in bewilderment as to the variance in naming, structure, and arguments for the various projects? And then the output you received from executing the command was different depending on which project you were running against?

Enter the OpenStack Unified CLI to level set these commands. The Unified CLI not only attempts to create a consistent feel between the OpenStack projects, it also is a pluggable architecture to dynamically provided commands, depending on which OpenStack components you had installed. For instance, you don't get OpenStack bare metal unless you have Ironic installed.

In this session we will deep dive into the OpenStack Unified CLI. We’ll show how it works behind the scenes, and we’ll discuss its available plugins. We’ll also provide some troubleshooting guidance for those times when things don't work as expected.
schedule.problem_addressed: Our goal here is to familiarize more people with the OpenStack Unified CLI and help them move away from the project dependant CLI as more and more commands will become deprecated over time in favor of the python-openstackclient.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about how the Unified Client works, the base objects that come with it's installation, the pluggable objects that are available for the client and general inner workings of when you type openstack what actually happens behind the scenes.

schedule.title: Can OpenStack beat Amazon AWS in price?
schedule.description: Can OpenStack compute instances, block storage and object storage beat Amazon AWS on price? In this cross-public-cloud provider presentation Bruno & Bruno will walk you though the business case behind an OpenStack public cloud and show you how the numbers stack up in comparison to Amazon AWS discounted prices for reserved instances. From Cloud to BareMetal, from IO to Compute intensive, the will demonstrate the performance/price ratio of OpenStack, so you can make an informed decision on when it is best to use it.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session will inform you at what scale / point it is worth to roll out your own OpenStack private cloud versus using a public cloud provider.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: You will learn how the OpenStack costs add up, what cloud business case and pricing model looks like, how OpenStack compares to Amazon AWS in terms of price.

schedule.title: A Survey of Container Security in 2016: A Security Update on Container Platforms
schedule.description:
As the use of containers continues unabated, including in OpenStack projects like Kolla, Magnum, Kuryr, and others, it's important for developers and operators alike to understand where we stand in 2016 on container security. We had reviewed Docker engine security in a public cloud context at the OpenStack Tokyo Summit in 2015. A year has passed, and we want to look more broadly across the container ecosystem at recent security improvements and remaining open items.

We'll bring attendees up to speed on the core aspects of container security, and talk about ongoing work occurring in upstream open source communities since the Tokyo Summit. We'll also look at reports like the NCC Group report covering LXC, rkt, and Docker, noting valuable recommendations and topics along the way.

We will also discuss our own open source work to improve container security and to provide tools for improving application security for operators and developers alike.
schedule.problem_addressed: Container security remains a very hot topic as there have been so many comparisons with VMs and isolation capabilities since the rise in popularity of containers (and especially the Docker engine). We believe many attendees will want to hear the latest updates on container security and gain insights into valuable learnings and recommendations from people active in this space.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how isolation and secure capabilities are being added to various container execution platforms like LXC, rkt, and Docker, and what they should know about remaining weaknesses across these platforms as well as improvements that are underway for both host isolation, application isolation, and application security principles.

schedule.title: Snapdeal's Journey from Public to Hybrid Cloud
schedule.description: India's largest e-commerce marketplace, Snapdeal is migrating to a Hybrid cloud built on Openstack. India's growth story has been unprecedented lately fueled by the proliferation of smartphones. Snapdeal is at the center of this digital revolution being the largest e-commerce marketplace in the country. Snapdeal was born in the cloud, but public clouds stops being cost efficient after an inflection point. Last year we decided to build our own private cloud and in a short 10 months period we have successfully built our Hybrid cloud using 100% opensource, with Openstack being at the heart. Our cloud is spanned across 2 Datacenter regions, has highly dense compute architecture with 70000 cores, 10 PB of storage and a 100G SDN infrastructure. We are running on community release of Openstack Kilo customized for our needs. I'll share some of the choices that we have made & the key learnings during this phenomenal journey, followed by a quick demo of our hybrid capabilities.
schedule.problem_addressed: Setting out to build a production private cloud is a daunting task. Public clouds have evolved a lot & with all the hoopla around enterprises moving into public cloud, one would really question the decision of building a private cloud. In our experience building a private cloud can yield great cost savings and performance gains, if executed well. We adopted Openstack because of prior exprience with it & because of no other real alternate to build a large scale IaaS using opensource, with a healthy ecosystem of supported enterprise products. During our early exploration we came across many projects that failed to execute on a similar mission, mainly because they didn't embrace Openstack as opensource and treated it like an enterprise software. In our opinion the only way to be successful with Openstack is by understanding the minute details of the inner workings and code. The community is a great resource to build that knowledge but ultimately the team has to own the software.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: I hope to share our learnings from building a large scale Openstack deployment ranging from the key benefits of building and operating your private cloud at scale compared to a public cloud. I will go though the 4 key reasons to build a private cloud and the key principles that we set for ourselves and the capabilities of the cloud platform. I will also explain the design of our Hybrid cloud and how do we plan to operate in a hybrid mode. Lastly, I will share some inner design of our datacenter, openstack cloud and the orchestration layer we built on top of it to make it hybrid.

schedule.title: Enable GPU virtualization in OpenStack
schedule.description:
Nowadays, GPUs have become much more powerful while being energy efficient. With the rise in popularity of 3D applications, growth in Big Data analytics, High Performance Computing, and streaming video, GPUs are being pressed into service to gain performance. Traditionally in virtualization usages,  a physical GPU is allocated to a VM using PCI device pass-through, an approach that limits resource sharing. However, graphics virtualization support today enables GPU sharing on par with CPU sharing with tenant isolation, enabling cloud workloads to benefit from GPU processing while allowing cloud providers better returns on their infrastructure investments and thus reducing total cost of ownership.

This presentation will introduce how to accelerate GPU intensive workloads in OpenStack with Intel GPU virtualization technology. We shall demo its use in OpenStack. Come learn how to make your cloud richer and even more performant to meet the demands of the workloads of today and tomorrow.
schedule.problem_addressed:
There are many use cases for GPU virtualization.  Such as: 

  • 3D/2D graphics acceleration

                Game
                VDI

  • Media Transcoding

                Video conference, Content Delivery Networks

  • High Performance Computing (GPGPU)

                OpenCL
                Geometric computing, Scientific computing, Machine learning,
                Personalized medicine, drug discovery,
                Bioinformatics, Finance, Medical industry, Meteorology …

For example, in a virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI), GPU virtualization has opened a lot more doors for different applications, such as 3D, CAD, video editing and so on. Users who need access to those apps would greatly benefit from GPU virtualization. They would see far better performance than before.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
•  The GPU virtualization (GVT-g) basic concepts and knowledge. 
  •  How to enable GPU virtualization in OpenStack.
  •  The performance benefits to use GPU virtualization.
  •  GPU virtualization enabling in OpenStack.
  •  GPU virtualization use cases
  •  Users can setup a VDI or Media cloud easier.

schedule.title: Mainframes in the cloud
schedule.description: Major enterprise customers continue to have and make significant investments in the mainframe to support both legacy applications, and increasingly, next gen workloads thanks to the high levels of virtualization the mainframe can support. In this talk, we explore the benefits of adding the mainframe to you hypervisor mix and demonstrate deploying workloads in a multi-hypervisor environment.
schedule.problem_addressed: The mainframe is ideally suited to handling certain workloads and large scale management of virtual machines. Customers are also interested in protecting existing investments. By deploying OpenStack and connecting it to z/VM, customers can protect the investment while taking advantage of the mainframe's strengths.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The advantages of including System z in their OpenStack plans, the architecture of the solution and how it fits within a multi-hypervisor environment.

schedule.title: Barbican Workshop - Securing the Cloud
schedule.description:
Security is at, or near, the top of everyone's list of "stuff that's important," yet the management of security artifacts (such as keys and certificates) has been lacking a cohesive solution.  This is where Barbican comes into the picture.  Barbican provides secure storage and provisioning of secrets, including keys and certificates. 

This workshop provides a tour through the magical world of Barbican, led by core members of the Barbican project.

By the end of the class you will know:

  1. Importance of secret storage
  2. How to store and retrieve secrets with Barbican
  3. How to submit an order with Barbican
  4. How to create a container
  5. How to use quotas
  6. Uses for additional user metadata
  7. Dogtag Certificate System Integration
  8. Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) Device Integration
  9. Hardware Security Module (HSM) Setup
  10. Performance
  11. Barbican Dev-Ops Architecture
  12. Use cases for Barbican / Examples
  13. Castellan (Generic Key Management Interface) Use Cases
  14. Barbican's Roadmap
schedule.problem_addressed: Showcase the importance of Secret Storage and gain more awareness of the tools avaliable. This Workshop will get attendees familiar with tools (Barbican, Barbican-Client, Castellan) to use for securing their secret materials.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees of all skill levels can attend, from Beginner to Expert.

 By the end of the class an atendee will know:

  1. Importance of secret storage
  2. How to store and retrieve secrets with Barbican
  3. How to submit an order with Barbican
  4. How to create a container
  5. How to use quotas
  6. Uses for additional user metadata
  7. Dogtag Certificate System Integration
  8. Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) Device Integration
  9. Hardware Security Module (HSM) Setup
  10. Performance
  11. Barbican Dev-Ops Architecture
  12. Use cases for Barbican / Examples
  13. Castellan (Generic Key Management Interface) Use Cases
  14. Barbican's Roadmap

Attendees are not expected to have any previous experience with Barbican.  A basic understanding of security components (such as keys and certificates) and a basic understanding of REST is helpful, but not required.

schedule.title: Design Summit (Dev+Ops) - Placeholder
schedule.description: TBA

schedule.title: Help: I have Trove deployed, how do I build guest images?
schedule.description:
"Help: I have Trove deployed, how do I build guest images?"

This is the #1 question asked by new users of Trove, the OpenStack DBaaS project.

Trove allows users to provision and manage the lifecycle of over a dozen relational and NoSQL databases. To operate Trove, users register guest images for specific database versions, and users can then request instances, replicated pairs, or clusters of those databases. A vital step in making this possible is to build these guest images.

This talk walks users through the process for creating guest images using tools provided by the Trove upstream project. Attendees will learn about the Trove architecture, and learn how to use the OpenStack DiskImage Builder tool to build database images for operation with Trove.

The presenters are Mariam John (of IBM), Amrith Kumar (of Tesora) who are contributors to the Trove project, and Gregory Haynes (of IBM) who is a contributor to the diskimage-builder tool.
schedule.problem_addressed:
In order to use Trove, you need to register a guest image with Glance and Trove and at a later time users will be able to launch a database instance based on that image.

A guest image in Trove must contain the database that you wish to deploy as well as the Trove guest agent. OpenStack does not distribute guest images and therefore a deployer of Trove has to build guest images, and the guest image they build should reflect their own best practices for how to operate a database while also respecting a set of constraints placed upon it by Trove.

"How do I build a guest image for Trove" is the #1 question asked by deployers of Trove and while there is much documentation, blog posts and tips on how to do this, it continues to be a stumbling block for a lot of deployers.

The aim is to offer a hands-on workshop where people can learn about images for Trove and walk out of the room having built and deployed an image for Trove on a devstack environment on their laptops.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the Trove architecture, and learn how to use the OpenStack DiskImage Builder tool to build database images for operation with Trove. Specifically, attendees will learn about:

 

  • The architecture of Trove, and how Trove relates to other OpenStack services in a deployment
  • What is a guest image, and how does Trove use guest images
  • How are guest images created, what are some tools for creating guest images
  • Best practices in building guest images for use with Trove
  • Putting this all together, creating a set of elements to build a guest image
  • Debugging problems while building guest images
  • Writing custom elements for your guest images

schedule.title: HPC, Unikernels and OpenStack
schedule.description:
This session explains lessons learned integrating HPC workloads with unikernels on top of OpenStack.

HPC workloads are traditionally executed in general purpose operating systems running directly on the host. Virtualized and containerised environments using these base systems are being adopted to improve flexibility and manageability of the infrastructure. To this end, the MIKELANGELO project is using a lightweight unikernel (OSv) providing bare minimum, but fully virtualized environment to these workloads. We are going to present a flexible application management that has been implemented specifically to support integration with cloud middlewares, such as OpenStack. This allows dynamic composition and execution of workloads based on user's needs. OpenFOAM CFD is being used to showcase our approach, including an integration into OpenStack dashboard. Finally, we will show how the use of a flexible telemetry system delivers in-depth insights into the infrastructure and application.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Users of traditional HPC clusters are presented with a set of strict limitations in terms of the operating system and available software packages. Development and testing of HPC applications also typically involves specific configuration and compilation of the source code which cannot be easily tested in a development environment. Virtualization and the cloud itself offer significant benefits as well as drawbacks, such as performance loss and overall overheads of typical operating systems.

This session tackles an alternative approach to running HPC applications in the cloud exploiting the OSv unikernel. OSv has been designed from the ground up specifically for the cloud. However it suffers from several limitations in terms of HPC, which are discussed in this session: heavily parallelised workloads, Linux compatibility, HPC-specific infrastructure (e.g. RDMA NICs and NFS) and application management. We will show how these have been overcome using a widely popular OpenFOAM application.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session is going to explain best practices, pros and cons of using unikernel from the perspective of the HPC. It will explain the unikernel concept and approach, explain the architecture chosen in this case study and present its major limitations. It will use a real world application based on OpenFOAM CFD simulation to introduce the steps necessary to ensure full compatibility with Linux-based guests.

We are also going to delve into the highly flexible management layer of the OSv itself, as well as the newly developed application packaging mechanisms enhancing flexibility of running arbitrary workloads independent of the actual environment: local, private/public cloud or HPC. Pilot integration with OpenStack dashboard will be used as a real-world showcase.

The session will conclude by outlining several other benefits that the MIKELANGELO project focuses on and are tightly coupled with our choice of the unikernel-based HPC: improved paravirtual I/O and virtual RDMA.

schedule.title: Cinder Always On - Reliability And Scalability Guide
schedule.description:
Cinder (OpenStack Block Storage project) can be found in >80% of OpenStack deployments. Configuring it to be robust, resilient and fast is important. However considering its high customizability, such as choice of deployment architecture, volume backend or backup backend, an always on Cinder is not a simple goal to achieve.

In this talk we will explain how Cinder can be deployed in ways guaranteeing increased reliability and performance, as close as possible to "always on". We will walk you through latest innovations that are letting you keep your control plane and data plane up during upgrades, increased load or when experiencing breakdowns. These features include:

  • cinder-volume service in A/A mode
  • rolling upgrades support
  • volume replication
  • volume migration

We will also share insight on the improvements in these matters that are planned for the future cycles.
schedule.problem_addressed: We want to address general problem of availability, reliability and scalability of OpenStack Cinder control and data plane.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should walk out from the session aware of presence of various Cinder features that increase its control and data plane availability and with knowledge how to use them correctly for different tasks.

schedule.title: The Good, Bad and Ugly: OpenStack Consumption Models
schedule.description:
Panelist : Amar Kapadia (Mirantis), James Page (Canonical), and VS Joshi from EMC.

Moderator: Ashish Nadkarni (IDC)

In this panel, experts will discuss the pros and cons of various OpenStack consumption models. We will take a critical view of the various options that are available for building an OpenStack cloud. Is DIY the best path or are there trade-offs? Should you be concerned with vendor lock-in leveraging a distribution or turnkey model? What considerations should you take into account when deciding between these options of DIY or Distro or Turnkey? Join these experts as they discuss the good, the bad, and the ugly with each path to a building a successful OpenStack powered organization.
schedule.problem_addressed: Many attendees (about 50%) at the summit are beginners. The first thing thing that they need to understand are the basics of OpenStack..How it can be consumed? What are the various consumption models etc. This panel will throw light on the various consumption models..
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Basic understanding of various consumption models.

schedule.title: OpenStack CI/CD for Everyone Else
schedule.description: As a company that develops software on OpenStack, wouldn’t it be amazing if you could use the same robust continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) process that enables thousands of distributed developers to create reliable software at a blazing pace?  What if setting up this kind of system had an “Easy” button?  Well, the OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC) QA/CI team is here to help. We’ll walk through a series of best practices and lessons learned from setting up a CI/CD system using open-sourced tools. Your team will be able to leverage the same proven development process used by OpenStack developers upstream.  After this talk you’ll be able to increase your development team’s time-to-market,  efficiency and reliability, and you don't have to be a sysadmin or an IT manager to do it!
schedule.problem_addressed:
You are a developer who has been given the task of developing an application on OpenStack?  You now have to find out how you will handle your application management and development process.  Our aim is to assist developers in this position with that very question.  We will provide a proven set of tools used for application management and continuous integration based off our own experience developing applications on OpenStack.  These tools will allow the developer to leverage the battle tested software process used upstream.
 
Benefits:
- Defines an application management style
- Decreases time searching for tools implementing this style
- Allows developers to focus on code!
- Allows managers to have more transparency
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Configuration and Tools used for:
- Source control
- Bug tracking
- Continuous integration

schedule.title: RabbitMQ at Scale, Lessons Learned
schedule.description:
Operating RabbitMQ at large scale comes with it's own set of challenges. This talk will take you on the journey Cisco faced with operating a large (800+ node) environment inside a single RabbitMQ cluster. We will share the pains, lessons learned and best practices to stabilize and improve messaging performance and reliability.

This talk includes:

  • OpenStack service configurations related to messaging
  • Kombu driver enhancements
  • Considerations when virtualizing the control plane, and how default network buffer settings can be insufficient.
  • RabbitMQ Erlang arguments related to TCP_USER_TIMEOUT and their impact
  • The overhead of Queue Mirroring
  • Kernel level network settings to improve RabbitMQ failover and provide faster service re-connect
  • Alerting and Monitoring RabbitMQ
  • Recovering from a cluster partition
  • Architectural decisions
schedule.problem_addressed: Large deployments of RabbitMQ struggle with default kernel and system settings. Errors like MessageTimedOut and cluster partioning will be addressed.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will walk away with best practices and configurations they can make to improve the reliabilty and perfomance of messaging in OpenStack.

schedule.title: Interconnecting Neutron and network operators' BGP VPNs
schedule.description:
The networking-bgpvpn Neutron stadium project allows to create connectivity between Neutron Ports, via their Networks and Routers, to BGP/MPLS VPNs.

These VPNs are a cornerstone of telecom operators' backbones and interconnect datacenters, businesses or NFV POPs. Interconnecting them on-demand with Openstack is a critical piece of the NFV and hybrid cloud puzzles. This needs to be done in a controller-agnostic fashion to let automation and orchestration code be free of ties to a specific solution. The networking-bgpvpn project has been kickstarted in the Neutron stadium in 2015 to address this need.
schedule.problem_addressed: The networking-bgpvpn project addresses the goal of being able to use Neutron to create interconnections with BGP/MPLS VPNs outside Openstack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We will detail the use-cases for these BGP VPN interconnections, the basics of the API introduced, and outline how the BGPVPN service plugin and its drivers allow the implementation to be based on SDN controllers --three as of today-- or on the Neutron-based driver.

After telling you the story of the project and what you can do with it, we will explain how we worked in the Neutron stadium and the synergies found between Openstack and OPNFV, and tell you what is coming next.

schedule.title: Toward 10,000's containers on OpenStack
schedule.description:
Kubernetes, Swarm and Mesos have been shown to scale to hundreds or
thousands of nodes and tens of thousands of containers, handling
millions of requests per second. On OpenStack, they can be easily
deployed and managed by Magnum, but how do they scale? Building the
correct infrastructure plays a critical role in the performance and
scalability for the containers, and this needs to be implemented in Magnum.

Working toward this goal, we have built a collection of Rally plugins to
track the performance and scalability of both Magnum and the Container
Orchestration Engines (Kubernetes, Swarms, Mesos). We have been running
the benchmarks on large OpenStack environments to collect measurements
and study the behavior of the system. In this talk, we will present our
findings along with some of the best practices we found for operating
large container environments.
schedule.problem_addressed: Container service for large user base and large environment
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Best practices in tuning Magnum to serve large user base, and best practices in configuring Kubernetes, Swarm, Mesos through Magnum.

schedule.title: Inspiring the Future of OpenStack through Diversity
schedule.description: The incredible spirit of open source and a community-driven development approach has spawned one of the fastest-growing open source communities in the world, with over 54,000 members across 180 countries now contributing to the OpenStack platform in some form. While there is strength in numbers, there is also strength in diversity of viewpoints and perspectives, fundamental to guiding the future of OpenStack and ensuring its vitality. Join us for a captivating session that features TED-style talks from inspiring individuals within the OpenStack community who will share their experiences and insights, and help ease the path for others to join us on our journey. Potential speakers include individuals from EMC, Comcast, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Rackspace, SanDisk, and SUSE.
schedule.problem_addressed: To ensure OpenStack's long-term vitality will require a diversity of viewpoints and perspectives. This session aims to share experiences & insights gained within the OpenStack community -- both, successes & opportunities for improvement. This session also aims to grow diversity within the community by welcoming newcomers into the community.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Diverse perspectives around the importance of diversity in driving OpenStack forward in the future.

2. Insights into successes & opportunities for improvement.

3. Ways for newcomers to get involved & participate.

schedule.title: OpenStack Journey in Tieto Elastic Cloud
schedule.description:
Tieto is the #1 cloud service provider in Northern Europe with over 150 cloud customers in the region. Turnover is approximately €1.5 billion.

Chronicle our journey to a new operational meta for our OpenStack cloud. From humble beginnings, follow our path to operational freedom and the security of knowing that every change is proven and can be deployed safely at any time. See how we’ve built on the OpenStack-salt project along with utilizing CI/CD pipelines to allow upstream bug fixes, security patching, service lifecycle management all off a git commit. The session will feature live demos so come prepared to be blown away.
schedule.problem_addressed: There exists tens of deployment tools for OpenStack and it is almost impossible to choose right way without any experience. In this session we will presents our problems during implementation of OpenStack and SDN/NFV solutin in big Service Provider company comes from VMware and legacy infrastructure environment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to choose appropriate deployment tool (Fuel, TripleO, Ansible, Puppet, Helion) for OpenStack.

How to implement Neutron SDN/NFV plugin for Service Provider.

How to solve Day 2 Operation for OpenStack private cloud in effective way.

How you should divide steps for implementation of open source private cloud in enterprise service provider.

How implement DevOps workflow in standard enterprise Service Provider.

schedule.title: Expanding and Deepening NTT DOCOMO's private cloud
schedule.description: In the OpenStack Summit Tokyo, we've reported how DevOps works in our project ( http://bit.ly/2a8atnJ ) and what kind of operations are performed behind our private cloud system ( http://bit.ly/29Dw8FW ). Over the first stage of launching private cloud system, now we are aiming to migrate various systems included NTT DOCOMO's basic operation systems to our private cloud. To gather various systems into the one private cloud system enable us to reduce total cost of ownership. Today, We talk our strategy and technical knowledge to expand and deepen our private cloud for the migration.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Our presentation is roughly organized by 4 keywords shown in following.

  1. L2 Gateway
    One of the most important functional  change between our private cloud and operating systems is to create an intranet cloud system. We share our experience and problems in this case.
  2. Reference Model
    To achieve our strict security governance through system architecture on our private cloud, It has been necessary for users to perform various security tasks by themselves. We created the framework with open source software, called "Reference Model", which automatically produces web-oriented architecture based on security rules.
  3.  Automation on Security Update
    As our private cloud expands, We have faced with more and more security vulnerabilities through daily operation. We created an automatic tool for security updates, and share the some custom scripts for automatic Security Updates.
  4. GPU instances
    We launched GPU instances, and learned some tips before running them.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Our session is for attendees who want to know the strategy of obtaining users in your OpenStack systems, or who want to learn the experiences of migration operation support systems/business support systems.

 Thanks to the community, it becomes easier to manage and work OpenStack stably; however, there is still less information about ensuring in-house users, and difficult to know what functions are wanted by potential users. We are going to share our experiences and own tools developed through the migration of miscellaneous NTT DOCOMO's systems. Also, we share future challenges to make the private cloud functions more deeper.

schedule.title: Lunch (click for details)
schedule.description:
• CCIB - Level 0 - Exhibition Hall 4/5/7
  • CCIB - Planta 2 - Banquet Hall
  • Hilton Diagonal - Floor 1 - TBA
  • AC Hotel - TBA

schedule.title: CTO Perspectives on Service Function Chaining for OpenStack Clouds
schedule.description:
Service function chaining (SFC) is the underpinning of NFV, enabling operators to compose a dynamic sequence of network services suited for elastic service environments that ultimately determines the quality and efficiency of service offerings. Virtualized network functions is one step in the NFV journey, but they are insufficient without proper SFC.In this session, the panel of CTOS will discuss technologies that are available today and in development for the near future to drive more agile, dynamic SFC with granular service points and policies for OpenStack operators. Some topics to be discussed will include:  

  • Role of SFC in NFV  
  • Challenges of deploying SFC
  • Clarifying SFC, Service Insertion, Service Graphs
  • SFC Architecture Framework
  • Standards bodies: ETSI, IETF on SFC
  • SFC working groups and where to find more information
schedule.problem_addressed: The problems addressed include challenges of deploying SFC, how OpenStack operators can overcome those challenges.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn why the challenges exist, what are the technologies available today, and new technologies that are being defined.

schedule.title: QoS QoS Baby
schedule.description:
Quality of Service (QoS) is typically associated with networking, however it can be applied to all components that make up the cloud infrastructure (i.e. compute, network and storage).  In fact, unless a cloud-wide approach to QoS is taken, enabling QoS features may not have much of an effect on performance.

This session will explore the QoS features that are currently available or upcoming in OpenStack, with an eye toward coordinating QoS across the entire cloud infrastructure in order to ensure that the cloud will meet the demands of critical applications.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to ensure that critical applications get the cloud resources they need to run efficiently.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how to coordinate QoS across the cloud infrastructure for maximum effect.

schedule.title: OpenStack is an Application! Deploy and Manage Your Stack with Kolla-Kubernetes
schedule.description:
OpenStack consists of interrelated software components that control hardware pools of processing, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter that are difficult to install, manage, and upgrade. With Kubernetes, each of the services can be viewed as applications.  Combined, they form a complex application that Kubernetes is capable of managing.

Kubernetes provides high-level abstractions built around the needs of complex production systems like OpenStack. This provides an alternative approach to operations enabling clusters to be more easily operated, managed, and automated. In addition, Kubernetes has native tooling which simplifies otherwise hard problems like HA or upgrades.

In this talk, the kolla-k8s team will demonstrate how Kubernetes solves the "Day 1" problem of deployment as well as "Day 2" operations like configuration, reconfiguration, failure recovery, and upgrades.  We will also demonstrate a production ready, highly available OpenStack based on kolla-k8s.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack consists of interrelated software components that control hardware pools of processing, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter that are difficult to install, manage, and upgrade. With Kubernetes, each of the services can be viewed as applications.  Combined, they form a complex application that Kubernetes is capable of managing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the benifits of managing OpenStack with Kubernetes through its unique abstraction layer.

schedule.title: Holistic security for OpenStack clouds
schedule.description:
Nothing clears out a conference room faster than a discussion around information security. Securing complex computer systems, such as OpenStack clouds, is extremely difficult. To make matters worse, attackers can make many mistakes without consequences. A defender’s single mistake could lead to a breach.

Don't let fear rule the discussion around security.

Operators need a simple and scalable method for securing OpenStack clouds. That starts with grouping components into compartments and then looking at how those compartments interact with each other. Those interactions form the backbone of security policies and technical controls.

In this vendor-neutral talk, Major Hayden, principal architect at Rackspace, will break down the complexity of securing OpenStack clouds using real-world scenarios. Attendees will learn how to:

  • Divide OpenStack deployments into compartments
  • Analyze the interactions between each component
  • Develop security policies and apply technical controls
schedule.problem_addressed:
OpenStack clouds are complex systems and securing these systems requires a deep understanding of the interactions in the environment. However, OpenStack is made up of many smaller systems that can be grouped and handled in similar ways.


The basis of holistic medicine is that the human body is a mass of interconnected systems that must be reviewed as a whole but also inspected at a lower level. A deficiency in one area may show up as a problem somewhere else. Security teams can use this same strategy to tackle information security challenges in OpenStack clouds.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn vendor-neutral methods to secure OpenStack clouds (and other complex systems) using a holistic strategy.

 

This starts with an introduction to the concept of compartmentalized security in an OpenStack environment. Attendees will learn how to analyze a complex system, understand the sensitivity of data and where that data is stored.


Attendees will see how these compartments interact with each other and how to apply security policy to these interactions.  That will lead into a discussion around implementing useful security controls that are scalable and repeatable.

schedule.title: Build the Artificial Intelligence Cloud - Provision and Manage TensorFlow cluster with OpenStack
schedule.description: TensorFlow was a new open source platform for artificial intelligence by Google Brain Team. Because of its powerful features and high scalability, it gains extensive attention once open source. In the other hand, as the most widely used cloud platform, thousands of organisations host their data processing platforms on OpenStack with Sahara project. Can we bring TensorFlow together with OpenStack?
schedule.problem_addressed: There are two distinct procedures of machine learning tasks: Training and Serving. After TensorFlow 0.8, it fully support distributed training, and once we got the trained model, it can deploy to production in a cluster for serving. Both two procedures are natural supported by Kubernetes. And as we know, OpenStack is able to manage Kubernetes with Magnum project. So how we integrated the TensorFlow and OpenStack? Should we based on Sahara or Magnum or both? This session will give a brief introduction of TensorFlow, the distribution model of TensorFlow, discuss the best practices for integrating it to OpenStack, and give a demo of how this powerful deep learning platform to benefit from OpenStack managed cloud infrastructure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In the presentation, you will get an overview of how to serve TensorFlow upon OpenStack as the deep learning plaform. We will share the experiences of how to integrate TensorFlow to OpenStack efficiently.

schedule.title: Get more juice out of your Cloud - Dynamic Over Provisioning techniques
schedule.description:
In a multi-tenanted Enterprise Cloud deployment, every now and then, we face a situation where we wished we had more compute resource to service new requirements. Since capacity planning is not a fool-proof prediction of your growth, facing a resource crunch situation is inevitable. To mitigate this challenge, in this presentation, we will showcase techniques which you can use to run your cloud at maximum efficiency.

We will showcase how to make the entire deployment elastic by innovatively expanding and contracting memory / CPU overcommits without penalising performance.
schedule.problem_addressed: Despite capacity planning, very often cloud operators have to deal with sporadic growth requirements and end up losing customers due to resource crunch or result in poor performance of running workloads. Not every workload utilises the resources they are entitled to and there are some workloads which perform poorly due to crunch. Our presentation specifically addresses these challenges by providing new techniques to resource overcommits.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We expect attendees will :

1. Learn about the Existing Overcommit techniques in various hypervisors and how they work

2. Learn about various  techniques like Ballooning, KSM, Memory Compression and Transcendent memory.

3. Learn how to dynamically expand and contract VMs

4. Learn how to make Openstack to operate at maximum efficiency with minimum resources

schedule.title: Automating your manual test suite using a Tempest plugin, Scenario tests and Rally
schedule.description:
Testing an OpenStack deployment by running 100s of detailed manual test scripts is a very time consuming effort.  Luckily, the Tempest test framework has a plugin interface and scenario test framework that can be leveraged for automating detailed test scenarios.


In addition to standard scenario test, that drive the OpenStack REST APIs, it is also possible to create scenario tests utilizing the WebDriver API for simulating browser interaction with Horizon, for full end-to-end UI test scenarios.


Furthermore, a Tempest plugin can be installed into a Rally deployment, so you can leverage the power of Rally for persisting your test runs , as well as create reports and compare test runs etc.


This presentation will outline and demonstrate the entire process for automating a single detailed test scenario.
schedule.problem_addressed: Migrating manual test suite to an automated on via a Tempest plugin.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Reviewing a manual test scenario
  • Creating a Tempest plugin
  • Implementing a scenario test based on manual test script
  • Installing the Tempest plugin into a Rally deployment.
  • Running the test, viewing and comparing test results via Rally.

schedule.title: From Neutron to Neutron: SDN-driven backbone traffic engineering
schedule.description:
Several models for providing end-to-end traffic engineering between data-centers in carrier backbone networks through the interworking of Data-center(DC) and WAN SDN Controller will be presented. The model will enable seamless end-to-end service and traffic engineering from host to host and/or ToR to ToR across large National Service Provider backbones. A number of use-cases including the dynamic provisioning of virtual resources in Data Center as well as logical resources in transport network will be covered.  Options such as DC SDN Controller to WAN SDN Controller coupling with abstract Interface definition or extension of an unified control plane which spans the Datacenter and Backbone Networks will be discussed along with advantages and disadvantages of the options.

The direct sharing of information, via standardized information models, between SDN Controllers will result in improvements in efficiency, flexibility and improved elasticity of resources for modern Carrier Networks.
schedule.problem_addressed: The current challenge of today’s Cloud Architecture is the focusing on a single instance environment.   There is often a belief that a “cloud” is a single instance rather than a combination of many instances, i.e. multiple Data Centers, connected by multiple WANs. Today’s Traffic Engineering scope does not account for an end-to-end service, rather it’s based on Traffic Engineering within separated domains, i.e. a Backbone domain or a Data Center domain). Real end-to-end Traffic Engineering from an Openstack managed VM “A1” inside Datacenter “A” to VM “B1” inside Datacenter “B”, across a WAN(s) or Service Provider Network(s) requires an end-to-end view.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

  • The role of IP/MPLS Controllers in modern SP networks
  • The role of DC Controllers in modern DCs
  • The value of standardized information models for the sharing of domain specific information
  • The cloud is not just someone else’s computer but rather a complex entity with his own traffic engineering requirements
  • Requirements for seamless Traffic Engineering and potential solutions
  • The relationship with Openstack/Neutron and common SDN-Controllers

schedule.title: Metrics: Friends or Enemies?
schedule.description:
Measuring progress, effectiveness and success is a key in every organization from software development to services. The metrics are the same, and as always the devil is in the details.

In an open source environment the different actors need to use the same set of numbers to form a meaningful set of KPIs. As the traditional processes and ways of working go through a transformation period to adjust to open source methods, it is crucial to have the same changes applied to metrics and how they are used to get the proper feedback loop.

This presentation will go through the existing tools that provide measurements and describe the meaning of each. The presentation will also give an overview on how to use the values in an efficient way to become drivers of both business and development as opposed to a numbers' game.
schedule.problem_addressed: There are a large set of metrics measured and available publicly. When these metrics are not used in the proper way that can affect business and development strategy, presence in the community and community engagement. This talk intends to clarify what the available metrics mean and how they can effectively used.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn what the different measurements mean and how they can use them to get meaningful information and also have feedback about how they are progressing. The talk will provide information to both managers and developers by showing how they can interpret the same information in their own field to get the expected outcome and get closer to their goals.

schedule.title: OpenStack Operations Quick Ramp-up and Survival Guide
schedule.description: Every cloud lover is running the same OpenStack, but different people deploy and operate OpenStack in different ways. In this session we'd like to share our practices to ramp up an efficient OpenStack operations team, based on real-world experiences and retrospection from operating dedicated and local OpenStack clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed:
We are going to introduce the following OpenStack operations practices:

  • Everything as a Code, other than "Infrastructure as a Code". Use git to control even your operation runbooks. This will not only promote automation, but also force people to do things in simple ways (as putting Word documents into git will be silly).
  • Use Configuration Management tools for any cloud change, not only for deployment/update, but also for daily operations. This will force more automation into the team with less SSH ops.
  • Centralized Collaboration as ChatOps. Put everything into Slack and build up your operations workflows into ChatOps rather than using it just as a chat tool.
  • Carefully define the shifts, to help with both the SLA and the easier life of your operators. 
  • Essential processes for OpenStack Operations, including Incident Management, Change Management, etc.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will be able to learn the essential parts and real world practices of running OpenStack operations and an OpenStack operations team, especially for the organization that is new to OpenStack world.

schedule.title: Design Summit (Dev Sessions) - Placeholder
schedule.description: TBA

schedule.title: Migrating a bare metal server into the OpenStack platform: it's possible
schedule.description: After releasing our bare-metal offering based on OpenStack's Ironic, we had a choice to make regarding our current customers’ existing product and services. Being hell-bent on providing them with long term, viable solutions, we decided to convert as much of their infrastructure as possible to the new platform. From dedicated servers to fully Ironic-managed ones, Maxime Bélanger and Paul Millette will present a process that attendees can follow to convert servers and infrastructure, to adapt network models and to ensure compatibility between the two platforms. They will also walk through the tools developed and used through this conversion process and the challenges faced along the way.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Converging customer into a unified platform so that clients have full OpenStack experience
  • Migrating from custom cloud/baremetal platform to OpenStack
  • Seamless migration in production (no downtime, no impact on the customer)
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Cleanliness of the production data is really really important to achieve the migration
  • If your carefully orchestrate the migration through an automation process usign the proper tools is really important
  • Automated testing is the only way you can ensure your migration process is doing it right
  • Automation is the key here!

schedule.title: SDN Scale-out Testing at OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC)
schedule.description: The OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC), established by Intel and Rackspace, is created to accelerate adoption of open source cloud operating system while supporting open source principles. OSIC provides ready-to-use data center facilities to the OpenStack community for development and test.  This case study presentation highlights a scale-out test performed within a 3 week period using OpenStack Ansible Community based on Liberty with an SDN overlay network connecting 131 nodes running over 1,000 VMs. Tempest and Rally tests were conducted to validate functions including high availability failure scenarios. Join this session to find out more about OSIC and the SDN scale-out test configuration, scenarios, and results.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session shares the scaling tests conducted in the OSIC lab with insights on Neutron, control plane and data plane test results that will shed light on production scaling needs.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the test configuration, scenarios, what worked and what didn’t work so well. Potential production gotchas and areas to explore further will be shared.

schedule.title: Building your technology castell, cloud startup funding scene in Europe
schedule.description:
Startups have always been a critical force in driving innovation in software and platforms. OpenStack and Docker has spawned a vibrant ecosystem of startups that are finding innovative new ways to serve customer needs and deliver value on top of OpenStack and containers. However, access to capital to support development and growth within these companies is sometimes complicated, but also critical.  

This esteemed panel includes both startups that have been successful in attracting essential capital, and ventures capitalists who are actively investing in OpenStack and container technology startups. The panel will have a particular focus on the funding situation and startup scene in Barcelona and more broadly, in Europe.
schedule.problem_addressed: Stories about tech startups closing new rounds of funding are prevalent. Plenty of familiar VC and investment house names season the tech industry. Yet, many great alternatives exist outside of the traditional U.S. tech hubs, especially in Europe. This panel will attempt to shed light on the alternative source of funding outside of traditional U.S. tech hubs, especially in Europe and right here in Barcelona. The panel will share best practices on how to connect with the European VC community and also with the U.S. giants that may have extension operations outside of US.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to hear from the panel of experts that have invested and grown Barcelona's entrepreneurial ecosystem of startups, connecting Spain to the global tech community. They will also hear from European investors that directly invested in OpenStack and containers startups and their funding criteria. This is a must-see for would-be entrepreneurs looking for funding in Europe or for companies looking for partnerships with European startups.

schedule.title: Ops Log Book: Volkswagen’s Group IT Operations Team’s adventurous journey to the land of OpenStack
schedule.description:
Originally, the Group IT Operations team was responsible for managing infrastructure for the Volkswagen Group. The team operates central backend data centers, servers and core services for the Volkswagen Group - following a traditional Enterprise IT approach.

Then, in Q3/2015 the Volkswagen Group IT decided to go with OpenStack for their new internal private cloud project. And the Operations team had an additional task and a new challenge: Bring OpenStack into production and run it.

This was the day when the Group IT Cloud Operations team’s excellent adventure to the land of OpenStack and cloud began.

In this session the team will provide insight into the challenges it faced, the solutions it found, and the day to day issues it experiences with clashes between the classic IT world and the new cloud world.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Technical and organizational transformation is the biggest challenge for enterprise users of OpenStack - like Volkswagen. To be successful in this transformation means to cope successfully with conflicting requirements between traditional and Enterprise IT, and the requirements of the cloud universe with its rapid and agile approach. The majority of the challenges are related to culture, peoples’ mindsets, organization, workflows and processes - not to the technology of Openstack.

This session will provide deep insight into the challenges a traditionally organized IT department will face when adopting cloud as a delivery model for their services.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Get real life information and practical advice from an operations of a large organization and hear the success stories of the journey to cloud and OpenStack
  • The challenges a traditional IT team may run into with all the shiny new things like DevOps, agile development, cloud paradigms and methodology
  • Advice on how to cope with objections from traditional organizations and processes
  • Lessons learned about changes and (self-) transformations needed to benefit from cloud technologies and methodologies
  • Learn about a successful operational approach regarding OpenStack, the ecosystem around it, and the services & solutions a cloud consumer is interested in when using private IaaS & PaaS from an internal private cloud

schedule.title: Put a Lid on It! Secure Kubernetes Container Workloads with Production-Grade Networking
schedule.description:
Container orchestration engines like Swarm, Kubernetes and Mesos highlight the importance of network security that scales with growing deployments. With Cloud Native applications built by composing microservices, the ability to control traffic as it flows among these services becomes critical. 

The Kubernetes Network SIG worked over last year to define Network Policy with the ability to control traffic among containerized services. At the same time, open source projects Kuryr and MidoNet have been advancing to achieve network security for containers in a simplified, distributed architecture. Removing architectural bottlenecks, Kuryr + MidoNet efficiently implement security policies through the hardened Neutron framework for use by containers in large scale environments. In this talk, we will discuss the latest updates of the Kubernetes Network SIG group, insert Neutron as a networking framework, and explore Kuryr and MidoNet networking solutions with advanced use cases.
schedule.problem_addressed: Open access network policy of Kubernetes is not suitable for applications that need more precise control over the traffic that accesses a pod or service. For simple cases, this could be a multi-tier application where traffic is only allowed from a tier’s neighbor. For complex ones like cloud native applications composed from microservices, it is important to implement fine-grain policies to restrict traffic at the service or pod-level for isolation or compliance reasons.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendee will learn about Kubernetes Network Policy primitives as defined by the Kubernetes-SIG for basic network access control between pods. The attendee will learn how the Network Policy is implemented by the Kuryr project, which leverages Neutron abstractions to provide containers with networking. Last but not least, the attendee will learn how the open source MidoNet SDN solution supports network policies and the benefits that MidoNet brings to the Kubernetes container orchestration engine.

schedule.title: Incident response and anomaly detection using osquery
schedule.description: Attendees will learn about osquery and how it can be used to actively monitor an environment. The focus will be specifically around indicators of compromise and anomaly detection within an openstack environment. Additionally I will demonstrate how to extend osquery using osquery-python and write custom query packs to detect flaws.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Actively detecting anomolies within a typical openstack deployment
  • Quickly search for indicators of compromise across your entire deployment
  • Using differential changes to monitor environment for policy violations
  • Ensuring all nodes in a deployment are patched against the latest vulnerabilities
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to actively monitor a deployed openstack environment using osquery. Introduction to some security concepts around indicatiors of compromize and threat exchanges. 

Technologies discussed:

  • python
  • osquery
  • ansible for deployment
  • open threat exchange
  • splunk / elk stack

schedule.title: Open Networking in Action: SDN and NFV + OpenStack and Cloud
schedule.description: SDN and NFV are fast becoming de facto industry standards as networks become more virtualized and agile among a rapidly evolving ecosystem. In this panel discussion, networking experts from across leading open source networking organizations -- as well as large telco providers, including AT&T-- will break down the current state of open networking as whole, with particular focus on how NFV and SDN integrate with OpenStack and the Cloud. Learn how these components fit together across disciplines with OpenStack at the center among a diverse set of real-world use cases and applications. The group will discuss recent trends (including AT&T’s recently open-sourced ECOMP), current challenges, how things have changed over the past year and recent months, what is currently in motion, and predictions on where the market is heading.
schedule.problem_addressed: The transformation in networking is huge, and NFV and OpenStack are at the center. This panel will address how the landscape has changed; what users, developers, service providers and vendors should be on the look out for; how those pioneering the way forward have addressed challenges and sage advice for those just beginning to their own network transformations.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the latest trends in open source networking from leading experts across the open source and carrier landscape. Details on current and past challenges, newest trends, how NFV is tansforming the network, and how different organizations and communities fit together across disciplines. Experts will debate the state of the industry, possible solutions to current issues and provide perspectives on what's coming next.

schedule.title: Glare - a unified binary repository for OpenStack
schedule.description:
Glare (from GLance Artifact REpository) is a new service in the Glance project that provides a secure and customizable unified binary repository for OpenStack.

The idea behind Glare is to allow various OpenStack services to catalog different objects they use to operate. Images used by Nova to run the VMs are just the best known examples of such objects; other examples include Heat templates, Tacker blueprints, Murano packages, and so on. Obviously, this functionality is common for different kinds of objects, and is usually unrelated to the primary mission of respective projects using these objects. That's why we implemented a dedicated service that will take care of managing various data assets in OpenStack clouds.


The talk will describe how Glare helps to manage different artifacts across the cloud, how you can build your own private and secure catalog with artifacts for your service, what deployers need to know about the installation process, and what is coming in the future.
schedule.problem_addressed:
The goal of this session is to acquaint the community with the new Glare service, and to define its tasks and describe the features. This service fills a vacant niche in OpenStack and is intended to become a unified catalog of structured meta-information, as well as related binary data (with these objects comprising the 'artifacts').

 

In general Glare provides the following key functionality: It:

 * stores the objects reliably;

 * guarantees their immutability once they're stored;

 * provides search capabilities to find objects in the catalog;

 * controls access to the objects by enforcing usage and modification policies, sharing and publication scenarios and so on;

 * returns the detailed info about the requested objects;

 * enables fetching of objects and manages their lifecycle;

 * supports import/export the objects between clouds.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to:

* manage Openstack artifacts based on a Heat Templates example;

* create a new plugin using the oslo.versionedobjects framework;

* install and activate a plugin in Glare;

* integrate Glare with other services;

We will also look at Glare's architecture and its distinguishing features, such as versioning and multiblob support.

schedule.title: Towards micro-services & API-centric application development
schedule.description:
Micro-services and API is becoming a fundamental technology for cloud application development.

In this session we will discuss how to design and implement a cloud-based application by leveraging micro-services architecture pattern and API-centric model. We will examine how to partition an application into multiple micro-services and communicate them through APIs. We will illustrate the architecture using a media application that we have built in our environment. We will also describe how OpenStack API and services can play an important role in this architecture design. In particular, we will explain how to utilize OpenStack SDK to communicate with Nova and Swift services, via API, as part of the application logic.
schedule.problem_addressed: Application development is shifting to a new architecture paradigm that based on micro-services and API. Application developers are in the process of learning this new architecture pattern and wondering how OpenStak can benefits them as a developer. This session will examine how OpenStack SDK and API can be used for application development.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn the insight knowledge of how to build micro-services, API-centric application that run on top of OpenStack. The attendees will also learn the potential of using OpenStack SDK (Nova and Swift) in their application code.

schedule.title: OpenStack in the Wild! How to make OpenStack a reality in your company.
schedule.description: The advantages of OpenStack in the enterprise are well-documented: agility, flexibility, lack of vendor lock-in, focus on enterprise applications vs. infrastructure, etc. But the reality is that despite great advancements, OpenStack remains challenging for most organizations to implement. Stories of the Fortune 100 adopting OpenStack are inspirational, but many organizations lack the resources to successfully deploy OpenStack. This is compounded by a complex ecosystem--finding your way and getting started is tough enough! This session is designed for the enterprise IT leader evaluating the merits of OpenStack and considering implementing this transformational technology within their organization. We will examine the principal methods of consumption (appliance, distribution, hosted service, etc) and the pros and cons associated with each. Attendees will leave the session with tangible action items they can take back and get started with.
schedule.problem_addressed: Analysts (and indeed customers we talk with every day) suggest that the biggest challenge to cloud adoption and success within the enterprise is the lack of a comprehensive, well-understood and agreed-to strategy. Of course this problem isn't unique to OpenStack but cloud more broadly.... but in this session we'll focus on OpenStack specifically as it relates to defining the enterprise cloud strategy.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will leave the session having learned:

  1. The 3 major ways to use OpenStack
  2. How to navigate the ecosystem of options
  3. How to evaluate in-house technical engineering capabilities
  4. How to integrate OpenStack with legacy IT systems
  5. How to create a definitive enterprise cloud strategy

This will be an interactive session designed to enable attendees to go back and implement real change within their organizations.

schedule.title: Project: OPNFV - Base system functionality testing (Functest) of a vIMS on OpenStack
schedule.description:
Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) based on OpenStack as the VIM (virtual infrastructure manager) is a growing use case among leading Telcos around the globe. Orange Labs have been leading the “OPNFV - base system functionality testing” project that provides a comprehensive testing methodology, test suites and test cases to test and verify OPNFV Platform functionality that covers the VIM and NFVI components. This project uses a "top-down" approach based on ETSI NFV use-cases and open source VNFs for the functional testing.


This session will dive into the functional testing of a vIMS system based on Metaswitch's Clearwater, coupled with the open source tools Cloudify and Jenkins, for the full lifecycle orchestration and management including the monitoring, healing, scaling and software upgrade of such a complex system.
schedule.problem_addressed: OPNFV is a new project looking to bring together the diversity of open source NFV projects and is tightly coupled with OpenStack.  This presentation by the functional testing team at OPNFV will dive into how to achieve end-to-end lifecycle management and orchestration on OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to achieve real deployments that are fully automated, managed and orchestrated through their entire lifecycle - including scaling and healing with OPNFV, OpenStack, and Cloudify using the open source vIMS Clearwater as the test VNF.

schedule.title: OpenStack Requirements  : What we are doing, what to expect and whats next
schedule.description: Syncing of requirements for OpenStack projects is a very important task since the way python package installation with pip works, this means that if you get lucky you'll end up with a working system. If you don't you can easily break all of OpenStack on a requirements update. Global requirements gives us a single place where we can evaluate these things so that we can make a global decision for OpenStack on the suitability of the library. The requirements team is trying hard to fulfil the REQUIREMENTS of managed projects with validating different requirements updates, auto-update of upper constraints for requirements to name a few tasks.
schedule.problem_addressed:
The recently revamped requirements team has been doing a lot of work to stabilize and maintain the global requirements with a set of predifined tasks [1] defined. But managing requirements is not a task that can be fulfiled by a bunch of reviewers in requirements team. Its a community effort that everyone needs to understand and perform. This involves updating the global requirements, block certain versions for libraries which are or may cause issues with OpenStack projects, dynamically testing upper-constraint updates to name a few. This session is an update on all the work requirements team is doing and create awareness where we get more contributors actively reporting, maintaining and validating library issues.


[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/requirements-tasks
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1] Understand the processes in global requirements management.
2] Understand what upper-constraints are and why they are important.
3] Reporting, maintaining and validating library issues related to global requirements.

schedule.title: Unified Command client and SDK for OpenStack
schedule.description:
OpenStackClient (OSC) is an unified command client for OpenStack. It has implemented 5 core projects‘ basic commands, and provides a plugin mechanism for other clients to work with it. OpenStack SDK is a library providing APIs for those apps who want to communicate with OpenStack core services. Using OSC and SDK will avoid unnecessary dependency, and obtain well organized commands and APIs.

We have made great progress in these two projects (600+ commits) in 2016. Keystone has deprecated its command client. Nuetron is migrating from Neutron client to OSC. Nova has clarified that Nova client will be deprecated, and suggested to enhance OSC. 17 other projects have implemented their clients as OSC plugin. We also integrated SDK into OSC to implement commands.

OSC PTL Dean shared why we need unified client during the keynotes in Austin, but didn't give much detail. Now, many developers started to use OSC, and joined OSC and SDK community. So, it's time to know the inside of OSC and SDK.
schedule.problem_addressed:
OSC and SDK will make OpenStack based app development much easier than before.

When you or your app want to communicate with OpenStack core services, for example, if you want to create a vm, you need to use commands or APIs provided by python-novaclient. And you should use other clients if you want to do something else. python-openstackclient (OSC) and python-openstacksdk (SDK) provide us the unified command and API interface for OpenStack. With these two projects, you don't have to install or import so many clients in your environment any more. You will obtain well formatted and organized commands and APIs, which are much easier to remember and use.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees would learn the points below from this presentation:

1. Benefits of the unified OpenStack client and SDK

2. Internal architecture of OSC and SDK

3. Intergration other clients into OSC (plugin)

4. Integration your app with OpenStack SDK

5. How to use OSC and SDK in your environment

6. Future work in community

schedule.title: No team? No problem! (How a single admin manages 70 OpenStack nodes)
schedule.description:
One complaint we always hear about OpenStack is that managing an big environment takes a team of people, but we've found that it's simply not true.

In this talk, you'll see how switching to OpenStack actually saved us time and money by replacing a few dozen workstations with just two OpenStack clusters that consist of 70 nodes -- all managed by a single admin.

More than that, though, we'll talk about issues you're likely to face and how to solve them, as well as what we needed to do to make it possible for one person to manage all of these resources.
schedule.problem_addressed: One of the barriers to OpenStack adoption is the notion that it's hard to operate and squanders any hardware savings on hiring people to manage it, but it doesn't have to be that way. This talk shows the real world user experiences of an OpenStack user, Naturalis, and explains how other users can get the same results.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will:

  • See a comparison of managing the cloud versus managing individual workstations to achieve the same result
  • Learn about cultural issues involved in moving people from having "their own" machines to using VMs
  • Look at methods we've used to make managing the cloud less resource-intensive, such as scripts and other techniques
  • Find out what a lone admin needs to know to make this work

schedule.title: Best Practices for Deploying OpenStack Trove: An Inside Look at Database as a Service Architecture
schedule.description:
This hands-on workshop will will share best practices for operating Database as a Service using OpenStack Trove.  You will learn how Trove works along with ways to deploy, configure, and use OpenStack Trove. This session will also share how to use Trove to provision and manage both relational and non-relational databases, take and restore backups, create replicas and use database clusters.

You will be able to answer the questions:

  • How are different organizations using OpenStack Trove?
  • What are common architectures for deploying database as a service on OpenStack?
  • What are the supported databases along with the supported functionality?
  • What are the updates to the Trove project in the Newton cycle?
  • What are some common use cases for OpenStack DBaaS

You will also have live access to an OpenStack environment that includes Trove pre-configured with databases.  This will allow you to learn basic OpenStack database as a service concepts.
schedule.problem_addressed: Attendees not familiar with the OpenStack Trove project will learn best practices for deploying and provising Trove.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn about the highly scalable and extensible architecture of OpenStack, how projects interact in OpenStack clouds and how the Trove based DBaaS service leverages the compute, storage and networking services provided within OpenStack. They will learn how they can quickly deploy Trove and offer a self-service database provisioning system for a dozen commonly used databases including a number of SQL and NoSQL databases.

schedule.title: OpenStack on Raspberry Pi: One Byte at a Time
schedule.description:
Deploying an OpenStack cloud across multiple Raspberry Pi computers.  The idea that using multiple credit card sized computers that cost about $35 each to run an OpenStack cloud seemed like an intriguing idea.  The actual feasibility of it needed to be tested.  There are a few blog posts that describe the general idea; however, most of them were outdated and did not include the latest version of the Raspberry Pi, the Pi 3.  Using a cluster of these devices, we set out to see how feasible it would be to deploy OpenStack using only Raspberry Pi devices.  In total, between two of us, we had a Raspberry Pi 1, two Pi 2s, and several Pi 3s.

Our goal: To set up OpenStack on these minimal devices, across the internet in two physical locations.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• How to install and deploy an OpenStack cloud utilizing several Raspberry Pi’s across the internet at multiple locations. Overall we setup Nova, Keystone, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, and Horizon across these multiple devices.
  • After installation and configuration, how usable this deployment would be for various services.
  • Overall, the experience of learning how to deploy OpenStack with a very minimal environment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Whether or not deploying OpenStack using Raspberry Pi hardware is a feasible idea
  • The steps involved if one would want to repeat the process
  • Any challenges they would face when doing so

schedule.title: Stewardship: bringing more leadership and vision to OpenStack
schedule.description:
Are you curious about the newly formed Stewardship Working Group? Do you want to find out about the work we're doing?     Are you wondering how you can participate in the group? TC, PTL, or core reviewer burnout got you down?  Do you wonder what it is to be a 'leader' in the OpenStack Community?  Have you heard the term "servant leadership" but don't know what it means?

Then this session is for you! Consider this our in-person, live FAQ for the community. We will talk about some of the changes the TC has been considering making to governance policy, and some of the resources we're working with to help provide leadership growth within the community. We would also love to hear your thoughts on what leadership in OpenStack means to you. Facts and details provided by Thierry Carrez, digressions and jokes by Monty Taylor, musical interludes and philosophizing on servant leadership by Colette Alexander, and moderated by Amrith Kumar.
schedule.problem_addressed:
What does it mean to be a 'leader' in the OpenStack Community? How do I influence people and 'lead' without formal authority? TC, PTL, or core reviewer burnout got you down? Are you worried about taking on a role within our community, or in other places but not getting the right resources to do the best job you can as a leader? Tired of people trying to solve people-problems with tech? 

We'll be addressing the larger themes of effective leadership in general, and how we can support development of leadership in the community in the future.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Leadership training themes and ideas. Possible changes to the TC governance model. The value of visioning. What the Stewardship Working Group is actually working on. Participate in a conversation on what it means to be a leader in the OpenStack community.

schedule.title: Lessons from the Community: What I've Learned As An OpenStack Day Organizer
schedule.description:
With over 25 OpenStack Days slated for 2016 and the numbers rising for 2017, an increasing number of OpenStack community members are becoming involved as organizers for these events. You will hear the important lessons learned by several OpenStack Days organizers from around the world.

In this panel discussion, you will:

  • Learn about initial expectations for planning an OpenStack Days event.
  • Explore enabling more diversity and inclusion with speakers and attendees for each event.
  • Receive advice on soliciting speakers and sponsors for an event.
  • Discuss challenges that presented themselves during several different OpenStack Days events.
  • Lessoned learned and advice for prospective OpenStack Days organizers.

This discussion will share the various experiences of organizers from different corners of the OpenStack ecosystem to highlight their learnings and hands on experiences.
